0439023513|5.0|...THIS is how you conclude a series.     Many people will gripe about how this book didn't turn out the way they wanted it to. That is because Mockingjay was realistic. It was realistic about war, death, destruction, and the effects these things can have on the human body and mind. People will be upset because this book was not just about her choosing between Gale and Peeta. Even her relationships with her men become warped by the war. This book is not Gale and Peeta running around without shirts on vying for Katniss's attention, it's not about everyone the main character loves surviving to live happily ever after.    What this means is that the reader is swept up with Katniss. We fall when she falls, rise when she rises. It means that one of your favorite characters probably doesn't survive. It means understanding the price of war, a fitting lesson for the world we live in today.    Brava, Collins, for taking risks and not going the safe route. It makes all the difference.

6305428557|5.0|Don't be put off by the title - [[ASIN:6305428557 The Englishman Who Went Up a Hill But Came Down a Mountain]] is a funny movie with a lot of soul. It's about a Welsh town that wants their local hill to be recorded as a mountain on the official cartographers' maps. So, what do they do? Pile a bunch of dirt on it until it becomes high enough to be considered a mountain!    The story is heart-warming and light-hearted at the same time. There are humorous moments (such as various plots to delay the cartographers from leaving town), but the movie revolves around the industriousness and pride of the villagers. Exemplifying their attitude is Morgan the Goat, played beautifully by Colm Meaney. Originally an outcast, he rouses the townsfolk toward greatness. His speech defending the decision to enlarge the hill has a humorously stirring ring to it - reminiscent of Braveheart... but without the weapons. The fire-and-brimstone preacher also ends up becoming an absolutely lovable character.    Hugh Grant also gives a good performance as the assistant cartographer. I'd warn Hugh Grant though fans that he doesn't come across as suave and sexy as he does in [[ASIN:B0002W4SWC Bridget Jones's Diary]]. Rather, he's a bit insecure and occasionally bumbling. It's nice to see that Grant can play those roles as well.    My only complaint with the DVD is that the sound quality is horrible. Already, it's difficult for American-English speakers to understand the thick Welsh accents. However, the dialogue is very soft throughout the movie and I had to turn my speakers up much louder than I ever had before. Then, in those one or two scenes when the sound reached normal volumes, they nearly shattered my ears because I had turned the speakers up! I hope that's something that could be fixed for a blu-ray release. It would also have helped not to have somebody with a thick Welsh accent narrate (I know the director was trying to give the movie a colloquial effect, but it was really tough to understand at points).    Overall, this is one of those movies that I'm truly glad to have discovered. Nowadays, when so much of what hits the cinemas is simply garbage, [[ASIN:6305428557 The Englishman Who Went Up a Hill But Came Down a Mountain]] reminds viewers of time when movies were supposed to tell a good story.

B003SI7V30|5.0|Don't be put off by the title - [[ASIN:6305428557 The Englishman Who Went Up a Hill But Came Down a Mountain]] is a funny movie with a lot of soul. It's about a Welsh town that wants their local hill to be recorded as a mountain on the official cartographers' maps. So, what do they do? Pile a bunch of dirt on it until it becomes high enough to be considered a mountain!    The story is heart-warming and light-hearted at the same time. There are humorous moments (such as various plots to delay the cartographers from leaving town), but the movie revolves around the industriousness and pride of the villagers. Exemplifying their attitude is Morgan the Goat, played beautifully by Colm Meaney. Originally an outcast, he rouses the townsfolk toward greatness. His speech defending the decision to enlarge the hill has a humorously stirring ring to it - reminiscent of Braveheart... but without the weapons. The fire-and-brimstone preacher also ends up becoming an absolutely lovable character.    Hugh Grant also gives a good performance as the assistant cartographer. I'd warn Hugh Grant though fans that he doesn't come across as suave and sexy as he does in [[ASIN:B0002W4SWC Bridget Jones's Diary]]. Rather, he's a bit insecure and occasionally bumbling. It's nice to see that Grant can play those roles as well.    My only complaint with the DVD is that the sound quality is horrible. Already, it's difficult for American-English speakers to understand the thick Welsh accents. However, the dialogue is very soft throughout the movie and I had to turn my speakers up much louder than I ever had before. Then, in those one or two scenes when the sound reached normal volumes, they nearly shattered my ears because I had turned the speakers up! It would also have helped not to have somebody with a thick Welsh accent narrate (I know the director was trying to give the movie a colloquial effect, but it was really tough to understand at points).    Overall, this is one of those movies that I'm truly glad to have discovered. Nowadays, when so much of what hits the cinemas is simply garbage, [[ASIN:6305428557 The Englishman Who Went Up a Hill But Came Down a Mountain]] reminds viewers of time when movies were supposed to tell a good story.

B002ZG98LO|4.0|Predators was tasked with the impossible job of setting a bruised and battered series back on course while reminding people of the great film that christened the endeavor from the beginning. After the Aliens vs. Predator  films regulated the predators to bystanders in the sub-hack-and-slash horror genre, it had become evident that it was time for something different. I'm pleased to say that, while hardly the classic of the first film, Predators  manages to inject new life into a science fiction concept that is both exceedingly simple but also capable of a myriad amount of variation.    Predators begins with Royce (Adrien Brody) plummeting through the atmosphere, unconscious. He realizes that he has been equipped with a parachute that deploys automatically, saving us from an incredibly short film. Confused and lost, Royce finds himself in the middle of an unknown jungle, but still armed with whatever weapons were, presumably, on him before being whisked away. By starting in media res, the film shows the audience that it is interested in the same sort of lean, no nonsense storytelling of the first film. When Royce comes across several others who have been stranded along with him, including a Yakuza decked out in a full business suit, a wisecracking criminal, a female sniper, and, strangely enough, an ordinary primary care physician, among others, each character is drawn with nothing more than a quick sketch. We don't need to know these guy's backgrounds, we merely need to know that the series is going back to the mercenaries versus predators formula that has served it well in the past.    In one of the better scenes of the film, the stranded mercs come to a clearing to discover a series of strange moons and planets midway between waxing and waning in an alien sky. This is the twist that the predator sequels have been looking for ever since Predator 2 way back in 1990. By pushing the film outside of our solar system, the filmmakers have opened up a whole set of possibilities. The castaways not only discover that they are stranded on a game preserve (a twist that more closely allies the film with the short story, \\"The Most Dangerous Game\\"), but also suggests that there is some sort of civil war brewing between the predators. While many of these ideas are not fully capitalized on, they still show a sense of imagination and an earnest attempt to show the audience something we haven't seen in a predator film before. I especially enjoyed the showdown between the katana wielding Yakuza and a predator, a scene that begs the question, did the predators ever visit feudal Japan? Perhaps this can be explored in the sequel, Predatorses.    But even as the film attempts to show us something new, there is also a back to basics mentality in Predators. The events of the first film are even recounted by the sniper, Isabelle, who explains how Dutch managed to defeat a predator. This is a smart maneuver because it avoids unnecessary scenes in which the characters rediscover the strengths and weaknesses of the predators, finally catching up with the audience. It also tells us to ignore most of the sequels, suggesting that this is the true heir McTiernan's original, a connection the film highlights each time Alan Silvestri's original score swells. But Predators (plural) never quite matches the storytelling quality of Predator (singular). The tension between the castaways in Predators isn't used as well as the tension between Dillon and Dutch's team of mercenaries. The story itself seems somewhat episodic as the humans stumble along from one danger to the next, seemingly without a plan.    The biggest curiosity of the film, however, is perhaps the strange turn by Adrien `The Pianist' Brody. There is a certain amount of logic behind casting the wiry Brody in the role, since Danny Glover was also a step down from the vein popping biceps of Schwarzenegger. I'm pleased to say that Brody handles the role of action hero well. Not only has he trained for therole, but he manages to affect a gravel crusted voice that gives off enough of an I-don't-care attitude for us to believe that this Polish piano player is now a hardened killer. No, if there is any fault in the film it does not lie with Brody. It is the fact that the film, for all of its ideas, never fully comes together in order to create something greater than the sum of its parts. For many, this means there will be plenty of arguments about which is the true heir to the original film, Predator 2 or Predators.
B003JTHESA|4.0|I love maiden and at first the songs sounded plan. My review is short and to the point. It is called creativity and the band still is coming up with great melodies. It would not be my favorite release but I still love it.
B002VECM4A|3.0|I had high hopes for [[ASIN:B002VECM4A Precious: Based on the Novel \\"Push\\" by Sapphire]] after seeing the hype and awards it received. Indeed, I did think the acting was great, and appreciate the innovative use of camera technique. Unfortunately, I was disappointed with the overall product.    Part of the problem is that the film simply piles a lot of depressing twists and turns without any variation or break. I don't want to sound hard-hearted here - I understand that some people unfortunately do find themselves in such depressing situations. However, even movies that focus on hardship usually have some variation in the amount of depression plot twists they throw at the audience. For example, some movies show a character's hardship, but then end with her triumphant redemption. Other movies chose to intersperse moments of levity throughout the movie so viewers don't become dulled to the character's pain. I think [[ASIN:B000N6U0E2 The Pursuit of Happyness (Widescreen Edition)]] does this beautifully (I almost did cry for that one). This is CRUCIAL because in order for audiences to sympathize with a character, they have to like that character first.    [[ASIN:B002VECM4A Precious]] does none of that. Instead, it feels like the director is trying desperately to make his audience tear up by throwing one misery after another, without ever giving us a reason to like Precious herself. While I felt sorry for her plight, she also comes across as devoid of common sense and rude. She calls her child with Down Syndrome \\"mongoloid\\" (a racist term for Asians). Her greatest joy seems to be stealing a bucket of fried chicken. Meanwhile I never found any inner strength or inspiration in her that made me really want to root for her. Without that emotional anchor, I found myself becoming overwhelmed and ultimately desensitized to what she was experiencing. By the end of [[ASIN:B002VECM4A Precious: Based on the Novel \\"Push\\" by Sapphire]], rather than cry, I felt like, \\"oh, so that's howthe directors managed to make her life more miserable...\\"    There were a few times when the movie tries to lighten up, but these fail. For example, the scenes when she fantasizes about becoming a star were just way too long, and the style jarred too much with the rest of the film. Precious playing with her newborn baby in the pool and dunking him in the water was (I think) intended to be a moment of joy, but all I could help thinking was that this girl should not be allowed to keep the baby! Likewise, the ending doesn't really inspire much hope or warmth. In fact, the denouement happened so quickly I almost missed it.    I really wish I could give this film a higher rating. It does educate viewers about the very real problems that some young women struggle with every day. Also, again, the acting is superb. Unfortunately, rather than be drawn in emotionally, I felt detached from Precious. It's too bad, because just a few changes could have made this work so well.

Anna and Lucie do not deserve their fates, nor is there any trace of a Hollywood resolution. This is horror in its extremity. A masterpiece in blood...

B003EYVXYG|4.0|I had this pre-ordered on Amazon, but was thinking I should cancel due to all the negative reviews. I'm glad I didn't listen to the reviews. :)    The movie Survival of the Dead marks the first for a lot of things for Romero.    First is that it's the first time there is a direct sequel. The original trilogy and the two previous films were all related, but unrelated in term of the character connections minus a few references here and there in the films. In this version, Romero use the troops from his previous movie Diary of the Dead, who if I remember correctly, entered the main character's camper half way in the movie. It was an insignificant part of the movie Diary, but it was used as the foundation of characters in Survival.     The second thing is that this is the first time where Romero intentionally used comedy in his film. I'd say the originals had very few \\"outright\\" comical parts, but in the introduction before Survival, Romero comes on screen and explains that there are comedy in the film.    Overall I think the movie was great. The story of Survival is similar to the story of Day. There is an island with two leaders, one of which believe that all the walking dead should be put to the ground. The other believes that the dead should be kept, should be rehabilitated.     Overall the movie gets slightly ridiculous by the end. There is a part where they were using this \\"smart\\" zombie who rode a horse, and they believe that by eating another food source, it would prove that they can be trained to eat something besides human. I think Romero forgot that in the original Night, there was a zombie who ate bugs, so it's a bit of a delusion on the part of the survivors to think they can be trained to want something else. So I'm unsure exactly why Romero decided to go this approach, but my assumption is that he wanted to show that the characters in the movie just weren't thinking rationally and that since there is a on-going feud, the two sides are just taking the opposite approach just to disagree with one another.      As a fan of Romero's film, looking at his latest creation, apart from the original trilogy, I think Romero \\"missed\\" something here. Perhaps it's the comedy tone or whatever, but just something doesn't hit it right with the original. Perhaps it's a bit of nostalgia of the originals, or perhaps Romero lost touch with something, I just don't seem to think of Survival as anything that can compete with his original trilogy. I think he done the \\"smart\\" zombie idea a bit too much. As Captain Rhodes would have said, \\"They're DEAD!\\" I mean I think it's an interesting concept to think that maybe they're us inside that rotting exterior, but overall we just can't see them as that since they clearly want to eat anything living. Realistically, I guess one would look at it on a viral level, rather than a psychological level which seems to be the main theme in the current version of the film (understanding what they are, and trying to change their drive is a bit sort of like psychology, or maybe behavioral therapy for the dead).     Personally as a fan, I understand Romero's approach to trying to change the behavior and drive of the zombies, but Day of the Dead already proven that even going with the cognitive behavioral therapy approach, human nature is just too evil and greedy to do it properly. We get all that. Now it's time to move onto another theme besides behavioral or even the concept of a \\"smart\\" zombie. What we need is another theme that fans can go off one. We should go with the viral approach. Personally I think it would have been just awesome if Survival was about an island of researchers trying to work out a cure like in Day, but end up backfiring. That would have been great and no longer trying to make the audience buy into the whole \\"Let's train them, but let's show them that they can't be trained.\\" I recall Romero said anyone who died, and did not die of a brain injury, would rise back up. So with that in mind,it could present an interesting research potential for a movie.     Overall good movie, but hopefully next film Romero will try to do something drastically and not try to write the same exact story but differently. Overall for this film, it is good but just not good enough for me to consider it a part of Romero's legacy.
0439023513|4.0|As the fantasy genre goes, Ms. Collins is truly at the top of her game.  The Hunger Games books are packaged to teenagers, but I would wager that half of the people who read this series will be adults.  I daresay they will fare quite as well, critically, as Harry Potter and infinitely better than the Twilight series (which is as it should be).    First the good.  As the other two were, the story is a page turner from first to last.  Collins knows how to weave a tale with the sort of brilliance that people will be talking about for years to come. It is no mean feat to create an entirely new world full of horrors, chaos and the unfamiliar without tripping accidentally into the esoteric.      Another wise move by Collins was to keep from falling into the trap of making Katniss too infallible.  The 17 year old blunders her way through Mockingjay as she did through the other two -- with unflinching bravery punctuated by a bad temper and questionable decision-making.      Peeta's handling, though heart-wrenching, is also brilliantly done.  Collins allows bits of the old Peeta to come through even after his torture at the hands of the Capitol.    Now for the bad.  Mockingjay was significantly more violent and graphic even than the other 2 books in the series. In fact, it seems that the book was written more to adults than kids.  I wouldn't let anyone under the age of 14 near this.    Furthermore, the crucial scene between President Snow and Katniss is quite unfulfilling.  Granted, Ms. Collins does this in the name of plot twist, but one feels that she could have added the twist without compromising that dynamic.    Last, I couldn't help but be disappointed in the handling of Gale.  He gets more and more unlikable as the series progresses.  By the time Mockingjay gets to its final chapters, I'm asking myself what Katniss ever saw in him in the first place.    But for these drawbacks, I'd have given the book a 5 star rating...and I still give the series a 5 and suspect it will be in the hands of teenagers for many years to come.
B0001FR3IQ|1.0|...and even more clich&eacute;s.  I have a problem with clich&eacute;s, especially when they can't seem to back themselves up with anything substantial as a form of recompense.  Instead, films like `Gothika' lather on the `been there done that' with a heavy hand, sprinkling in generically effective `thrills' in an attempt to say \\"see, we made you jump in your seat\\".  Sadly, those thrills die off pretty quickly when the plot holes become more and more evident and the straight-laced direction seems to take the viewer on a path leading to predictability.  Think `The Sixth Sense' (that ending was such a rip-off) meets `What Lies Beneath' with an R rating and some gore.  Oh yeah, and far inferior performances (what WAS Penelope Cruz doing?) and a script that didn't understand itself.  You will spot the bad guy the minute you see him, even if the ridiculous plot tries to convince you it's someone else, and you will roll your eyes at the films conclusion, which overworks the CGI to deliver an action sequence that takes you outside the creepy tones they were trying to create here.  Insane asylums are typically scary places, but you really have to work your environment to create lasting chills.  `Gothika' seems content with just dropping us in a scenario that seems scary and then leaving us to get bored with it.  Thankfully the overrated Halle Berry manages to attack the flow of the film with a performance that reads surprising sincerity.  It's just a shame that sincerity is misplaced.

Each song has a different groove, but they all have a great sense of forward momentum that will bring a smile to your face. In this era of Tweener tunes, computer generated rave up \\"music\\" and other assorted garbage it's a real treat to hear a band that totally has its act together and is having a great time performing.

B003EYVXUK|1.0|10/23/2010 Update;  I've read every critics review I could find on this film.  I bought into the hype and went to see it. I stand by my original assesment based on viewing only the trailer. There is no conceivable way (and I will argue this point to the ends of the Earth, try me) that Reeves' film is better than the original--as some critics claim. He lifted the color palette, the tone, a number of key shots, dialogue, etc. from the original film. That doesn't constitute a better film. It's like plagiarizing an essay. You take an original, obscure source. You take all of it's original ideas and principles and you twist them around and reorganize and restructure them to fit your purpose. People may marvel at your \\"fresh take on the original source material\\", but it's certainly no masterpiece. Case in point: The pool scene. Easily the most memorable scene from the original film. Reeves sets the whole thing up quite well, but when it comes to the execution he falls short. Throwing about 50 more gallons of blood in that pool and making the one kid cross diagonally behind Owen and having a decapitated head fall down in front of his face came off hokey and lame. And that's just my point: if the point was stand off and away from the original film, why is so much blatantly ripped off from it? Why do you have essentially the same shot in the pool scene only changed by about a 45 degree camera angle? It seems he didn't make his own adaptation of the novel, but rather tweaked a screenplay to mediocre results. Don't get me started on the acting by the two leads. I had high hopes for Chole Moretz--what a disappointment! There was not one moment of her performance when I did not know she was just regurgitating a memorized script. And Kodi Smit-Mcphee, OH. MY. GOD! Could his performance have been any worse?  It was like they dubbed his voice with the english dubbing from the original movie. No emotion, no depth, no nothing. If you do not know what I mean.  Watch just a few minutesof the original movie with english dubbing and you will see.    This remake is just another example of why the original is a masterpiece, and a genuine work of art that deserves ALL of the   praise it has gotten. Especially praise of the two lead actors--  Lina Leandersson and KÃ¥re Hedebrant. The film's director, Tomas Alfredson, took his time in   finding the two young actors (incredibly, their first time on screen) and   their performances are magnificent, heart-wrenching and totally believable!    I give the remake zero stars.  Yes, that is correct, ZERO! \\"What an idiot. You gave it one star\\".  Only because Amazon FORCES me to chose from 1-5 stars. But thanks for your comments.    My original review is below:    Let me be the first to give this remake zero stars.  I just saw the first trailer which was recently released.  From WHAT THEY SHOW in the trailer, it is identical to the Five Star original--\\"Lat den ratte komma in\\" (Let the Right One In)  Do your self a favor, check out the reviews for the original and then watch it!  I am curious to see Chole Moretz as Eli or whatever the vampires name is in the remake.  Her role as Hit Girl in Kick Ass was superb.  Unfortunately, Kodi Smit-Mcphee is playing Oskar.  My first exposure to Kodi was his role in \\"The Road\\".  I was not impressed.  In fact it was some of the worst acting I've ever seen. 1594488843|4.0|I love books that give me `aha' moments. This book was one.  I've read a lot about the new generations and how managing them is different.  Part of me thought that these people don't want to work hard or put in their time and they want instant gratification.<br /><br />Now I'm starting to get it.  Daniel Pink explains that the very nature of work has changed from routine tasks to knowledge-based work.  The carrot and stick way of motivating worked okay for routine work, but it can actually be de-motivating for knowledge-based work.<br /><br />To be successful in today's word, you need to engagement and mastery. Another way of looking at this is being in the `flow.'  The challenge is how to motivate employees for this.<br /><br />A particularly effective method is allowing employees to spend a set amount of time each week working on personal interest projects.  The key is that they have to product something at the end, e.g. a prototype, a new process, etc.<br /><br />Daniel gives some interesting examples of successful companies doing just this.  Google lets employees spend 20% of their time on their own projects.  This is how Gmail and Google news were created.  So it works.<br /><br />Humans need a higher purpose for their life and if a company can capture this, they'll have productive employees.

It's so refreshing to watch him on screen. He reminds me of Troughton with a little bit of Davison/McCoy thrown in. He doesn't overdo it, he is very subtle, and that is totally refreshing. Especially after the overly emotional Tennant, who by the way was still excellent in the role.    The show is heading in a different direction, different but the same. I for one welcome the changes as all true fans should. Doctor Who is all about change. If you can't accept that just stick with Series 1-4.    The Eleventh Hour was by far the best Series opener since the shows return in 2005. For those that say that Series 5 has no replay value I couldn't disagree more. I have watched that first episode 3 times now since it first aired and still laugh at many of the scenes. And as is evident on Youtube, I am certain that I am not the only one that has tried fish custard! (It's good by the way)    The only clunker this Series had was The Victory of the Daleks, and I put that down purely to direction. The rest of the Series was golden, especially the Weeping Angels two parter and the jaw dropping finale. Fezzes are cool indeed!    In short, Series 5 is just really good science fiction. I'm excited to see what happens next!    If you are a fan show your support and pick this up! I know I will. And for goodness sake write your own review and give this the 5 stars that it deserves! Don't let the naysayers bring the rating down, most of them didn't even give the new series a chance.

0439023513|4.0|***SPOILERS*** I REPEAT...***SPOILERS***  (I'm writing this intro to my review after I wrote the actual review)  I did enjoy the majority of this book. Just a warning however, that probably after you read this review, you will feel like I hated it. And that is just because once I got writing, I had to vent about all the things that I felt could have been executed better. But I repeat...overall, I liked the book, and it had it's redeeming factors, I'm just slightly frustrated that it didn't end better. And I don't mean it was supposed to end the way I wanted, I just would have liked to have been satisfied with the ending. Anyway, see what I mean? Once I start it's hard to stop. On to the review...    ***ONCE AGAIN. SPOILERS***     1. Negative: I felt that there was too much copping out when things were just about to get good. On several occasions I found myself slightly annoyed that I was missing out on what seemed like important events because Katniss was either knocked out or drugged. Then Katniss would resurface, and all we would get was a quick little synopsis from Haymitch or Boggs on what happened while she was out.  I know that Collins likes to leave some things to the readers imagination, which is one of the things I like about her writing style. But I felt that it happened way too often in this book, and that rather than trying to let us figure out what was happening, she was trying to save time and space by skipping a first-hand account of the event, and then giving a recap in a paragraph or two. The most annoying of these situations, of course, was at the end of the book.    2. Positive: There were several unexpected twists in the book. For example, Peeta getting rescued and turning out to be hijacked. Despite my being a hopeless romantic, and becoming physically ill at the loss of Peeta's love for Katniss, I enjoyed this twist because I enjoy unpredictability, which leads to a negative. The unpredictable ENDING of the book. An unpredictable ending would have been fine, if it would have been more satisfying, however, this ending was NOT satisfying. More about that later.    3. Negative: As mentioned above, I enjoyed the twist with Peeta's hijacking experience. But I feel like the recovery and the clean up of the situation was handled very poorly. As a reader of the  Hunger Games I grew to love Peeta because of his adoration for Katniss. However, in his time of confusion, I lost some of that love I had for him because his personality had completely changed. No time was spent on helping the reader to grow to love him again. For the hopeless romantics reading this series, myself included, the lack of Peeta/Katniss moments was extremely disappointing, and they were so necessary for the redemption of Peeta's character. Never have I hated a line so much as, \\"Peeta and I [grew] back together.\\" We needed to witness them growing back together. Obviously, pages spent solely on this purpose would have been somewhat tedious, but I think they should have been intertwined with Katniss's recovery and a more in depth description of what happened to Panem and its people after the war. That being another disappointment of the book.     4. Positive: Collins's strengths. Imagery. Character development. Action sequences (when they're present) The ability to keep the pages turning at an unremarkable pace. The ability to scare the crap out of me and horrify me with the gore. Yes. This is a good thing.    5. Negative: The treatment of Gale's character. There was plenty of Katniss/Gale time, for those readers who were Gale fans. Despite being a Peeta fan, I liked Gale as well. He and Katniss had a special relationship. But to me it felt like the situations Gale was put in demeaned his character. Mainly the ones involving Katniss. They hardly had any happy moments together. Mockingjay seemed to negate Gale and Katniss's relationship and made me question Katniss's difficulty over choosing between Peeta and Gale. It especially bothered me thatif it weren't for a minor statement about Gale living in District 2, we wouldn't have known what happened to him, and Katniss's lack of caring seemed utterly ridiculous.    6. Negative: THE ENDING. I know it sounds like I hated this book, or at least it's about to, but honestly, I absolutely LOVED this book. I was about to declare it my favorite, right up there with the first one. Then I read chapters 25 through 27, and all was lost. Even as I approached the end of the book, and the remaining pages began to dwindle, I became skeptical that all loose ends would receive tying, but the knowledge that it was Suzanne Collins's story and that she would want to give it a just ending, gave me the hope to keep reading. Unfortunately my faith in Collins was slightly misplaced. Simply stated, the ending was too rushed. Now for my not so simple statement.     We have spent the entire book, the entire series actually, waiting for the Capitol to be defeated, and more specifically to see Katniss go in and take out Snow. And neither of these events were given justice. Once again Collins copped out on us by knocking out Katniss via an explosion so that we miss the entire first-hand account of the defeat and surrender of the Capitol. What should have been an event spanning numerous chapters, was summed up in a couple of sentences. We also didn't get to witness any of the action with Peeta, or Gale, or Haymitch, during the surrender. Our emotional ties to these characters, and especially to Katniss, would have made these non-existent chapters real page turners, and where the action could have been pure perfection, it was instead non-existent. It was the epitome of anti-climatic. And although it would have been nice to witness the action, it's not even the the fact that we missed the final fall of the Capitol but more the fact that Katniss missed it, that was so disappointing. When countless numbers of people we care about die; Rue, Cinna, Finnick, Prim, District 12; and then the one person we truly feel has the right to avenge their deaths doesn't get to, it's very unsatisfying. On top of that, the whole situation defeated the purpose of Katniss's character, and honestly made her appear to be, for lack of a better word, wussy. So instead of what could have been an amazing attack on Snow, we get to witness the pointless death of Prim. But even this event could have been justified. Katniss had already started to lose herself at this point in the book, and Prim's death could have served to bring her back and given her that final push to kill Snow. Instead it sends her into a never ending state of depression, once and for all putting an end to the character we fell in love with at the beginning of the series. The perfect example of this is reflected in Katniss agreeing to another Hunger Games, which really bothered me.  Whether she was already planning on killing Coin or not, she never would have said yes. It would have completely reversed everything she had been working for. And if at this point she was already planning on killing Coin, what was the point in saying yes to another games, because either way, another hunger games was never going to happen. Another note on this situation, the death of Coin needed more explanation. Coin's assassination. The trial. The trip back to 12. The recovery of Panem. Peeta's return. Gale's departure. Katniss's recovery. Mrs. Everdeen. The rebuilding of 12. Peeta and Katniss's relationship. All of these things and more, still needed to be addressed after the infiltration of the Capitol, and three chapters simply was not enough to do it.    I guess the point I'm trying to make is that the ending of the book seemed to negate the entire purpose of the other two books and the first 24 chapters of the third. Obviously the first two books were mainly about the Hunger Games, but there was always that knowledge that Katniss and her gang were eventually going to have to defeat the Capitol and end the Hunger Games, so the fact that we don't get to witness Katniss accomplishing that, totally defeats the purpose of her character. The other main aspect of the book that kept readers interested was Peeta and Katniss's relationship. This too fails to deliver, in that we hardly get to see them interact with each other at all, and when they do interact, it totally negates everything you loved about their relationship in the first two books, and then there is nothing to redeem their relationship in the end. The two main plot points, the defeat of the Capitol for those who cared about the politics of the book, and Peeta and Katniss's relationship for those who were more involved in the romance of the book, were both sore letdowns, thus nullifying the point of the first two books. Both of these issues, however, could have been resolved if more time was offered on the ending. To spend two books, and twenty-four chapters of the third book, leading up to the collapse of the Capitol, and then not even witnessing its collapse, and then expecting to be able to tie up all the lose ends, and rehabilitate all the broken relationships within three chapters, is where this book failed tremendously. It almost seems like Collins got behind on her deadline and had to end what could have been another ten chapters (which fans would have read eagerly) within less than half the pages. Why spend so much time perfecting a story, only to write a sloppy ending?     Obviously if you've read the first two books, you have to read the third. Mockingjay won't disappoint in the levels of suspense, character development, and surprise.  But perhaps when you get to the end of chapter 24, stop reading, and imagine that Katniss storms into the mansion and shoots an arrow right through Snow's heart. I realize these are just my opinions, and obviously I don't know everything, and maybe some of my solutions to these issues are too formulaic, but hey, I'm not a writer, which maybe completely discredits this review. All I know is that if I was writing a story about characters I cared so much about, I would want them to receive their due-justice, and I would want my readers to at least feel satisfaction at how the story ended. And NEVER would I want my final installment to make the first two books I wrote seem entirely pointless. Like I said, I'm not a writer, but as a reader and as a fan of the books, I was let down. I realize everyone has their opinions, and it's impossible to make everyone happy, but Mockingjay left me so unsatisfied and more importantly, disappointed. I know I've used those words a lot, but I don't know how else to phrase my feelings after finishing this book. Never, in my entire life, have I read a book that left me feeling the way this one did, and this spawns from the love I have for the first two books. Its characters. Its story. To have anticipated the ending of a story for so long and then to have said ending handed over to you in such a sloppy manner is nothing more than frustrating.    Maybe Collins is happy with how it turned out. Maybe she wanted her readers to come away with a more realistic war survival experience, which I respect. Maybe the whole point was to realize the power one person, one symbol, can have in strengthening the people. I honestly don't know. The Capitol was taken down, but what does that even matter if the main character doesn't really learn anything, or grow from it, or even worse completely loses herself? Whatever Suzanne Collins was thinking when she wrote this ending, I don't think she anticipated the chance that it could possibly ruin the first two books for some of us. Personally, I enjoy reading the books that I love numerous times, and my only hope is that I can continue to read The Hunger Games and Catching Fire, despite knowing how it ends. I'm sure I'll find it within in me to do so, as I'm sure many of the other fans will, but I suppose that's because I have an imagination that will hopefully allow me to disregard this failure of an ending. The only thing I'm not sure I'll be able to escape it the overwhelming sense of disappointment...
0307271862|2.0|While I much prefer Nesbo and Nesser, I've read of few of Mankell's books from the Wallander series and enjoyed them for the most part. It's as though the author said \\"2 1/2 inches is thick enough, I'll end it there.\\"

0439023513|5.0|This is a book i have been anticipating for a long time. after reading catching fire i was stuck on the edge of my seat wondering what was going to happen. none of my thoughts brought me to where it ended up. this is, before anything else, a book about war and the cruelties with which war is fought. the book begins with peeta's capture and katniss's introduction into life as a refugee of district 13. her home, along with the entire district has been destroyed by the capitol. this is were the revolution begins.     in this heartbreaking and often sad story you see what people will do to gain power, or to keep it. lines get blurred between whats right and wrong and who is a villian. the book is a wonderful and very real end to a great series and i know that the characters that i came to know will be with me in other books i read and when i hear about wars being fought. the story is masterfully told and a joy to read even when the story turns sad. i am happy with the ending and looking back it really was the only way if could have happened. anything else would have been an insult. if you liked the hunger games and catching fire this is a must read that will shake your to your core and leave you breathless and satisfied at the end. i know i will recommend this trilogy in its entirety for many many years to come.     May the odds be ever in your favor!

0393327655|5.0|No matter how you slice it, the answer to the question \\"does God exist?\\" can only be answered by faith.<br /><br />That means that any answer, whether it augurs for a particular religion or even -- as Harris argues in this book -- no religion at all still remains merely a faith affirmation.<br /><br />While Harris argues mightily against abuses of religion, none of his arguments per se actually operates as an indictment of religion itself.<br /><br />Here's why:<br /><br />1) When Harris says that those who abuse religion make his case for its elimination he is perhaps on his weakest ground.<br /><br />Sure, terrorists, suicide bombers and their ilk -- who purportedly do their evil deeds at the behest of some perception of God -- are definately not religion's poster children. But the same could be said of abusive husbands and crooked politicians. While abusive husbands certainly undermine the currency of marriage, they still nonetheless do not make the case for the elimination of marriage itself. In a similar vien, crooked politicians to be sure threaten the viability of our political institutions but they don't make the case for the elimination of those selfsame institutions.<br /><br />In other words, if the existence of any institution could be argued for based on the idea that people from time to time abuse it, then I would daresay no human institutions would survive.<br /><br />2) Where Harris says that people who believe in God are wrong simply because their beliefs are rooted in a faith system not subject to empirical re-evaluation, he makes an interesting but ultimately irrelevant point.<br /><br />Sure, if one is to be Christian or Moslem or maybe even any other religion that has ever existed, one no doubt does accepting for all time and ever again the unique \\"truth\\" of their belief. But the same can be said of many other human attitudes. In this regard, I find it most interesting that the vast majority of people share not only their religious attitudes, but political and class affiliations with those of their parents. Viewed from an outsider's perspective, it's almost as if having been indoctrinated as children, people do their utmost to avoid further serious thought on these issues. (And interestingly enough, where ostensible changes in faith affirmation are made, the changes made are usually mild, viz: Catholicism to Lutheranism and the like.)<br /><br />My point here isn't that it wouldn't be nice if people were genuinely more willing to seriously reconsider their attitudes on such matters. Rather, I believe that the criticism propounded by Harris again unfairly suggests too draconian a solution to the alleged \\"problem\\" at hand, namely: people's unwillingness to respect other religious viewpoints. (Would that this could apply to politcial views as well!)<br /><br />If Harris is saying that religous adherence should be regarded as criminal where it requires one to do violence to others or otherwise strip others of their rights, he will find me in fast agreement. If, however, he is suggesting that only by throwing out the baby with the bathwater (getting rid of religion itself) then I think he's wrong by over reaching.<br /><br />3) When Harris fails to give serious credence to the good religion has done, I think he errs.<br /><br />In this regard, Harris is both dismisive and abusive towards those who would point to the great kindnesses performed in the name of religion or those who did them. Prior to modern times, he would say, religious people did a lot of good stuff but back then everyone was religious anyway. Two problems emerge here:<br /><br />The first is that religious people are still doing good and important stuff today and the second is that since the emergence of our species we're talking about like two thousand generations of humans. Are we seriously to sweep all their progresses under the same dismissive blanket? For me, the answer is clearly not.<br /><br />4) When Harris xenophobically picks on Moslems, he's hitting below the belt.<br /><br />The likes of Robert Spencer aside, Islam is NOT religion of intollerance or hate. Uncited in his book is the constitution of Medina, authored by Muhammed himself requiring Moslems to respect the Jews living in their midst not to mention countless hadith (or sayings or Muhammed) and lines from Qur'an which testify to the value of human life and peace among peoples. (In this regard, the Qur'an specifically preaches respect to what it refers to \\"as peoples of the book\\" therein refered to as Jews, Christians and Sabians...the last being perhaps a catch all phrase.)<br /><br />Also, as conceded by even Harris, it cradled the candle of human inquiry while the rest of the planet was living in the night of the dark ages. Even today, Moslem Americans are eagerly and peacefully taking their place along with the rest of us. In the mid east, Egypt and Jordan have already made peace with Israel to be sure to be followed by others.<br /><br />Sure, we could say that we'd like to see Moslem countries adopting this policy or having that political system but to say that there's something about Islam itself that makes people particularly intollerant or hateful is just unfair and wrong.<br /><br />Also, it's xenophobic too. Trying to engender anti Islamic feeling this close to 9 11 is just like similar behavior conducted against the Japanese after 12-7-41 (when Pearl Harbor was attacked by the Japanese starting American invovlement in World War II).<br /><br />5) When Harris picks on Christianity he's being unfair.<br /><br />As Harris correctly points out, the Bible does have its less than perfect moments (where it seems to preach death to homosexuals and others who don't believe for example). However, what he fails to observe that when the Bible's most incendiary passages were written, they were actually an improvement over other practices then in place. One example of this is the so called Moloch sacrifice where worshippers of Moloch would actually incinerate their children as an offering. (Interestingly enough this activity took place at Gehenna now rendered as Hell, yet another fiery destination, albeit for those more deserving of such a post death punishment.)<br /><br />The point is that the Bible pointedly disavowed this conduct and in so doing sided with the forces of history that would later abolish slavery and support the expansion of women's rights. To be sure, a lot theologians were dragged kicking and screaming along the way but significantly -- and as conceded by Harris himself -- they were made passengers to other theologians who read their Bibles to support freedom and rights for women.<br /><br />To be sure, certain passages in the Bible are less than progressive but as a whole the Bible is a unique document telling as admittedly oftentimes more about the people who wrote than how we should or indeed actually do lead our lives. And to be fair, in its early history and even among the visionary today it still serves as an inspiration for change.<br /><br />6) And finally Harris doesn't explain how -- if religion is so bad -- how the 20th centuries two greatest killers were both atheists.<br /><br />Yep. It's sad but true. More than Hitler, either Joseph Stalin or Mao Tse Tung alone caused more death individually. That's not to exonerate Hitler (who did remain a Catholic in good standing until his suicide in 1945) but rather to underscore an important point.<br /><br />When it comes to being either a homicidal murderer or just a doer of evil deeds, religion is no impediment. To be sure, it can and oftentimes has been the espoused basis of the wrongdoing but to suggest that one's propensity to violence correlates only with their religious beliefs is...well...just ridiculous.<br /><br />All these points being made, I do think this in an important book for the issues that it raises. From Neitczhe forward, it's been intellectually cool to press the whole God question, intoning on the one hand the various inconsistencies in religion while using the other hand to point dismissively at those who would beleive.<br /><br />But those good, decent law abiding people who choose to believe are within their rights...their right to follow the faith of their forebears, to have a relationship with God consistent with their faith systems and finally to be let alone as long as they're not bothering anyone...least of all, those among us who would claim to know \\"the right answer\\" or more repugnantly deign to impose it on someone else.ld actually incinerate their children as an offering. (Interestingly enough this activity took place at Gehenna now rendered as Hell, yet another fiery destination, albeit for those more deserving of such a post death punishment.)<br /><br />The point is that the Bible pointedly disavowed this conduct and in so doing sided with the forces of history that would later abolish slavery and support the expansion of women's rights. To be sure, a lot theologians were dragged kicking and screaming along the way but significantly -- and as conceded by Harris himself -- they were made passengers to other theologians who read their Bibles to support freedom and rights for women.<br /><br />To be sure, certain passages in the Bible are less than progressive but as a whole the Bible is a unique document telling as admittedly oftentimes more about the people who wrote than how we should or indeed actually do lead our lives. And to be fair, in its early history and even among the visionary today it still serves as an inspiration for change.<br /><br />6) And finally Harris doesn't explain how -- if religion is so bad -- how the 20th centuries two greatest killers were both atheists.<br /><br />Yep. It's sad but true. More than Hitler, either Joseph Stalin or Mao Tse Tung alone caused more death individually. That's not to exonerate Hitler (who did remain a Catholic in good standing until his suicide in 1945) but rather to underscore an important point.<br /><br />When it comes to being either a homicidal murderer or just a doer of evil deeds, religion is no impediment. To be sure, it can and oftentimes has been the espoused basis of the wrongdoing but to suggest that one's propensity to violence correlates only with their religious beliefs is...well...just ridiculous.<br /><br />All these points being made, I do think this in an important book for the issues that it raises. From Neitczhe forward, it's been intellectually cool to press the whole God question, intoning on the one hand the various inconsistencies in religion while using the other hand to point dismissively at those who would beleive.<br /><br />But those good, decent law abiding people who choose to believe are within their rights...their right to follow the faith of their forebears, to have a relationship with God consistent with their faith systems and finally to be let alone as long as they're not bothering anyone...least of all, those among us who would claim to know \\"the right answer\\" or more repugnantly deign to impose it on someone else.

0446563048|5.0|I really enjoyed this book.  It is extremely well written in a sort of conversational tone, that keeps it interesting.      I read a lot of business books, and this one was a fun read.  Tony Hsieh is quite an interesting character.  He's experienced outstanding successes throughout his life so far, but seems quite unaffected by it all, as he comes across as being very down to earth.  Who wouldn't want to work at a place that he was running?

0439023513|4.0|Okay, so I'm a bit torn with this book.  As usual Collins delivers a story full of question, new friends, new betrayals, and is nearly impossible to put down. I loved it, I'll probably read it again and I recommend reading it! My only complaint is I feel the ending was rushed. But then maybe the author did this on purpose? Katniss's life has been nothing but unstable with people leaving her and never coming back. I guess I can reconcile with this, but not the very end.<br /><br />Like I said, it felt entirely too rushed from the moment the silver parachutes were delivered to the children in the capital until the end. Maybe Katniss is too broken to give us anymore of an end than this?  What do you think?

B0034G4OU4|3.0|Whether or not \\"Eat, Pray, Love\\" adequately represents the bestselling memoir of the same name ([[ASIN:0143118420 Eat, Pray, Love: One Woman's Search for Everything Across Italy, India and Indonesia]]) by author Liz Gilbert or not doesn't really matter.  Is it the fault of the filmmaker or the writer when the piece attempts to hit the side-of-the-barn of greater meaning and just barely skims the surface?<br /><br />\\"Eat, Pray, Love: the Phenomenon\\" recounts the year long journey of writer Liz Gilbert as she recovers from a messy divorce and an unfulfilling affair/relationship with a very 21st century self-absorbed pragmatism that appeals to both aging flower children and their \\"look-inward\\" progeny.  By combining worldly angst with the spiritual fascination of Eastern religions made fashionable by the Beatles in the 60s, Gilbert attempts to fill many different types of holes in the spirit of self-development simultaneously.  Although she succeeds somewhat in her book, director Ryan Murphy's film stalls when it fails to define itself within a particular genre.  Not that this ambiguity alone causes the film to fail--it ambles along prettily enough but unfortunately without enough thrust to make it stand out as a must-see event.<br /><br />Murphy/Gilbert's audience contains the wide subset of Oprah Winfrey watchers--those of the \\"live your dream\\" mantra that desire nothing more than to be able to make a lucrative career out of facilitating something they love.  Gilbert surely fits the bill here: her publisher financed her journey of discovery to three foreign countries where she could eat, pray and love her way to bigger pay check.<br /><br />Just what Gilbert is fleeing is up for grabs.  Her marriage to Billy Crudup doesn't work and neither does her affair with the young hottie actor (James Delicious Franco)--how sad is that? Neither of these man ask her to sacrifice her livelihood for them--Crudup is depicted as financially dependent on her and Franco blows her off emotionally when he realizes she is looking for him to save her.  As she wanders through the streets of Rome on the first leg of her trek, the audience senses her confusion--is the melancholy of her past preventing her from enjoying the pleasurable sensations of the present and the future?<br /><br />The juxtaposition of the \\"Girls Just Wanna Have Fun\\" theme while in Italy--mucho plated food porn, the hum of Vespas and so many leather-clad Italians looking chic in skinny jeans--with the austere loneliness of the Augusteum in Rome to depict the change that the world and time has on one's inner identity marries the desire to splurge with a sad introspection that tries too hard--hinting at depression but not quite spelling it out.  Perhaps knowing that Gilbert actually battled depression with medication may help the audience better understand and relate to the confused emotional shifts through which the main character traverses.<br /><br />Murphy avoids this descent within the modern mindset for pharmacopia focusing instead for more than half of the film on Gilbert's sojourn at the Indian ashram.  Is he commenting on the fact that the status of being a spiritual seeker is just part of a look at the ersatz intelligentsia--those who emote often and within the boundaries of copious self-development/how-to realms where just living a good life with great companions isn't quite en vogue anymore?  Is he telling us that enlightenment has become the newest and trendiest goal?  In this sense, is it any wonder that the most predominant self-help guru of our time (Oprah Winfrey) has taken Gilbert under her lofty wings and is promoting not only the author's bestselling memoir but also the film and its star, Julia Roberts?  Is he helping to build an \\"Eat, Pray, Love\\" franchise that advocates taking a long break from reality while attempting to peel away the layers that hide the inner self?<br /><br />Who knows?<br /><br />Gilbert's activities at the ashram are never really defined--her inner journey becomes trite and cutesy rather real and mind-boggling.  Whatever conclusion she reaches doesn't really reach the viewer--the audience waits for the \\"love\\" leg of the triangle because that is how a film as attractive as this with an attractive main character should end--with love.<br /><br />All this would be very cool if the film defined itself in more universal terms.  As a travelogue, the cinematography lovingly captures the Eternal City, the riotous humanity of Mumbai and the lush jungles of Bali with a glossy expertise that would do both National Geographic and Travel & Leisure proud.  As a romantic fantasy--girl is married to wrong guy, has affair with younger actor and than finds the hunkiest Brazilian ex-pat this side of Ipanema even after gorging herself with indulgent amounts of pizza, pasta and gelato--'EPL' might work.  However, the screenplay makes the mistake of dictating a New Age panacea for the ennui of modern life.  Whereas the average viewer expects a visual nirvana of charming faraway places, he/she is force-fed the not-so-palatable pill of Liz's self-absorption.  The result confuses; the storyline seems over-edited.  The overall messages gleaned from the experiences in the three places don't really flow with any real meaning because even though we are treated to some voiceover, we are not privy to the progression (if any) of Liz's without-rhyme or reason thought as we are in her equally poorly formatted book.  The bulk of the film's time is spent focusing on the routine of the ashram in Ganeshpuri, India where Liz fumbles through meditation, her early morning devotionals and some textbook feminism regarding the woman-unfriendly aspects of marriage.  Why she is there and what she hopes to gain other than to meet the guru of her ex-boyfriend is never fully mapped out.  She snaps with frustration at the gruff Richard from Texas (Richard Jenkins) also playing pilgrim at the hermitage and he speaks in zen to get her to the point where she can get between the sheets with Javier in an Indonesian hut.  Huh?  The amalgamation of the material world with that of the spiritual and the sensual covers too much ground in too little time while the formulaic ending of girl riding the waves with her new man trivializes the more somber issues introduced but never fully developed or rectified in the first two segments of the trek.<br /><br />As \\"Eat, Pray, Love\\" can't figure out just exactly what its point is, the actors can't figure out how to play it. Choreographed with MTV-ish segments of Julia as Liz in different parts of the world, the audience strives to participate but cannot--Liz's pain is explained, but it is too nebulous--too deep and indulgent to fully understand.  All Julia Roberts can do is alternatively look sad or happy.<br /><br />Bottom line?  Watching Julia Roberts travel to three different world venues as she ponders the big question of life's meaning doesn't quite work in this film adaptation of Liz Gilbert's bestselling book \\"Eat, Pray, Love.\\"  A better venue for this soul trek would have been a National Geographic series where the points of scenery and dogma could have been better exemplified in documentary format.  Think [[ASIN:6302426227 Japan (4 tape set) [VHS]]] hosted by Jane Seymour.  More clearly introduced information would have fleshed out the personal stuff giving the audience more background and less muddle.  Recommended only for those who like Julia Roberts and simplified travel journals with fairytale endings.<br />Diana Faillace Von Behren<br />\\"reneofc\\"ather real and mind-boggling.  Whatever conclusion she reaches doesn't really reach the viewer--the audience waits for the \\"love\\" leg of the triangle because that is how a film as attractive as this with an attractive main character should end--with love. Recommended only for those who like Julia Roberts and simplified travel journals with fairytale endings.  Diana Faillace Von Behren  \\"reneofc\\"
B002RWKSII|1.0|I love Brian and I love Gershwin but I hate this album. The arrangements are cheesy and very derivative of earlier beach boys/brian wilson solo albums and brian's doesn't have--and never had--the vocal skills to sing these songs with the nuance they deserve. Really painful listening to this. For some delightful interpretations of the Gershwin canon, check out \\"Naughty Baby: Maureen McGovern Sings Gershwin.\\"
1592402038|4.0|Lynne Truss has written a book that must be placed in its own category: a best selling book on punctuation. It probably surprised even her. And it intimidates at least this reviewer, fearful of the numerous red marks he would receive, all due to a penchant for an extra clarifying comma or two, and a few other weaknesses. The title is a play on the changed meaning of the sentence if there is a comma after \\"eats,\\" and is accompanies by a panda, who would nominally be a cuddly grazing vegetarian but becomes a harden killer who takes a gun, and kills (all due to the lack of a comma.)<br /><br />Truss describes herself as a \\"stickler,\\" and says she was driven to write the book after viewing one too many mistakes with signage. Fair enough. And she has produced a thoughtful, amusing book on the need for greater precision in our written communication. The book is chock full of anecdotes, starting with just plain dumb to ambiguous errors, and then stresses the importance and evolution of punctuation. For example, the reader will learn that the novelist, Milan Kundera once fired a publisher who insisted on replacing a semicolon with a full stop (that's a period for Americans). Likewise, the Irish nationalist, Roger Casement was \\"hung by a comma.\\" Anton Chekhov once wrote a story entitled \\"The Exclamation Mark.\\"  And Aldus Manutius the Younger, in 1566, where a lot of this story all began, stated that the main object of punctuation was the clarification of syntax (surely a statement I will now routinely quote in defense of my \\"extra\\" commas.)  Ms. Truss (and hopefully the honorific is acceptable) manages entire chapters on the apostrophe, the comma and the dash.<br /><br />I figured she was just being a bit playful with her \\"over the top\\" mock outrage. She might actually be a pleasant dinner guest who would not exhibit the same fastidiousness in regards to wine selection or cutlery placement. But still, I did have a few problems. Principally, she is BRITISH! (Please, no scathing comments... some of my best friends are...) And while her book might work quite well in the UK, and assorted dominions, there is that \\"translation\\" problem for Americans that is not addressed, as well as others, and it goes beyond full stop, period. There must be at least 500 words that are spelled differently in the United Kingdom and the United States: color, colour, etc. The road to damnation would be paved with the supposed good intentions of impose one spelling standard or another. For better or worse, and it is generally the latter, at least the French have an Academie franÃ§aise, where language usage can be adjudicated... and new words invited, particularly in computer technology, so English words do not soil the sacred tongue. But English speakers have no such body, and Truss writes her book, sorta, as though one existed (herself?) I noticed that she gave only a passing nod to this problem when she said: \\"...that American usage has retained a lot of the formal niceties that we have dropped. They also often use a colon after \\"Dear Andrew\\", while on this side of the Atlantic we dither about whether even a comma looks a bit fussy.\\"<br /><br />Indeed, that sentence contains one of my favorite bugaboos about punctuation in an international setting. In British usage, the comma is outside the quotes; in American usage, the comma is inside the quotes. So, what is an honest \\"citizen of the world\\" to do? Be consistent, or give a nod to punctuation relativism!<br /><br />Enjoy the anecdotes, enjoy her tongue-in-cheek (hopefully) style, but an English speaking \\"citizen of the world\\" will find only paltry directions to \\"correct\\" behavior in this book. 4-stars for at least the wit, and yes, we should be at least clear and usually unambiguous in our written communications, and no doubt, Aldus Manutius the Younger would concur.some of my best friends are...) In British usage, the comma is outside the quotes; in American usage, the comma is inside the quotes. So, what is an honest \\"citizen of the world\\" to do? Be consistent, or give a nod to punctuation relativism! 0316098337|5.0|This is truly one of the best books I've read this year. I hope to see it make a name for itself. Weeks after reading it, I still think about it.<br /><br />The story is about a college-aged woman who is abducted and made to live in a room by her captor for years on end. During this time, she has a child whose entire world is this room. She turns it into an entire world for him. The few objects in the room are personified (Chair, Bed, etc.) The mother is able to entertain the child in the most creative of ways (making a snake out of egg shells, etc.) The child lives for each week's \\"Sunday Treat\\" from the kidnapper. Even though the mother tells the child that nothing on television is real or that it's on another planet, he doesn't question where his Sunday Treats must come from. However, when the child is finally old enough to understand, she tells him the truth about everything and they plot their escape. But how could a child who has only ever seen the world of Room survive on the outside?<br /><br />This is a psychologically dense story that truly pulls you into another world within our world like very few novels can. I rarely read books more than once, bu this one is definitely a candidate for a re-read.

B001VZY4M8|4.0|I guess I'm really making an effort to listen to old music at this point. I liked Neil Young as a kid when my parents listened to him, so I thought I'd pick up what seems to be his most acclaimed album. And it's really good!    It's a pretty good mix between his style of rock and roll, usually accompanied by Crazy Horse, and some more individual, folksy numbers. Although I've always identified Young by his frequent harmonica playing, it didn't really stick out here, only appearing in one song, with the focus more on occasional piano and much more frequently, his guitar. A few of the songs have messages, which I associate with him just as much as anything musical, although some seem to be simple songs with no purpose other than to sound good. I've grown accustomed to his high pitched voice by this point, but even if you have some trouble with it, I think it would be hard not to like at least something from this album.    To me, the highlight of the proceedings is \\"Southern Man\\", a pretty hard rocker that jams along for five and a half minutes, and has a pretty searing anti-racism message to it against the south. Along with a song from his next album, it inspired the recording of \\"Sweet Home Alabama\\", which is a connection I wouldn't have expected. \\"Oh, Lonesome Me\\" is the only song on the album not written by Young himself, and has a really nice melancholy to it. \\"When You Dance I Can Really Love\\" is another stand out rock track, while the first two songs are more subdued, and another two favorites. \\"Cripple Creek Ferry\\" is the kind of song that would never be a single because it's too brief and singular, but is always welcome as an interesting way to begin an album, or make a transition, or as in this case, close things out. It's a nice cap to a record that I couldn't find much I didn't like in.
B00003CXZ4|5.0|Everything about this movie is perfect. It's suspenseful and keeps you guessing until the very end. One of Christopher Nolan's best--if not THE best--films. I highly recommend it.
B0034G4OYU|4.0|In May of 2009, the crew of Space Shuttle \\"Atlantis\\" oversaw the fifth and final service mission of the Hubble Space Telescope, known to NASA as STS-125 or Hubble Space Telescope Servicing Mission 4. The mission called for delicate repairs and state-of-the-art upgrades, including the instillation of the Cosmic Origins Spectrograph (to study the formation and evolution of galaxies) and the Wide Field Camera 3 (which captures images on the visible spectrum). The crew also had to replace one of the telescope's three Fine Guidance Sensors, six gyroscopes, and two battery unit modules. The mission was a success, completed in less than thirteen days. Because of the crew's efforts, Hubble will continue to operate until at least 2014, when it's expected to be replaced by the James Webb Space Telescope.    IMAX's \\"Hubble 3D,\\" narrated by Leonardo DiCaprio, is in part a documentation of this mission, made possible due to the IMAX Space Team and the specially designed IMAX 3D camera. While hardly an exhaustive account - which is just as well, since it would mean having to endure confusing technobabble and a slew of acronyms known only to NASA personnel - we're shown some impressive spacewalk and repair footage, aided greatly by the ever-present backdrop of Earth. We also get some insightful, if brief, moments with the \\"Atlantis\\" crew, including a demonstration of how to dress for a spacewalk, a discussion of some of the tools they will be using, and an amusing look at what an astronaut can eat and how it's made possible. There's a general sense of enthusiasm amongst the seven astronauts, although that may have more to do with the camera crew than with the actual mission.    We don't get a detailed history of the Hubble itself. Its original 1990 launch, for example, and the subsequent three-year odyssey to repair its design flaw are mentioned in passing, drastically downplaying the time, money, and effort that was spent to get it working properly. You have to understand that this is by no means a cheap piece of machinery; its initial cost was estimated at around $400 million, and that figure has only increased with time. With so much invested in it, there was an understandable backlash when it was apparent that there was an error with the optical system, the returned images failing to achieve sharp focus. The cause of the problem was the telescope's primary mirror, which had been ground to the wrong shape - the edges were off measurement by 2,200 nanometers, and to give you some perspective, a single nanometer is about 1/100th the width of a human hair. The flaw was corrected in 1993 during Service Mission 1, known as STS-61, with the instillation of specially designed corrective optics.    Since then, Hubble has captured a number of remarkable images. Because of its orbit outside the distortion of Earth's atmosphere, there's virtually no background light, allowing for the sharpest quality pictures. Consider the Ultra Deep Field image, which captures a small section of space in the constellation Fornax and is composited from four months worth of data; it reveals a cluster of galaxies of all shapes, ages, and colors, and it remains to this day the deepest image of space ever captured, looking back approximately 13 billion years. The film takes data similar to this and transforms it into breathtaking computer generated flights through distant regions of space. One scene in particular takes us into the Orion Nebula, where a massive group of stars form in a crevice that spans 90 million light years. Given time, some of those stars may form solar systems very much like our own.    This is the second part of what \\"Hubble 3D\\" is: An awe-inspiring journey, a deeply thought-provoking foray into the great unknown. It has the power to make you think, to raise questions about ourselves, about where it all came from, about what it all means. It wisely avoids speculation; it merely presents the material as is, and your mind does the rest. The fact thatit's all presented in 3D only adds to the wonder. Plenty has been said about James Cameron's \\"Avatar\\" - and I've certainly contributed - but \\"Hubble 3D\\" is by far the best 3D film I've ever seen. Never have I felt so deeply immersed, so entirely a part of the world projected up on the screen. It reaches a level so rarely reached by the hordes of 3D movies released on conventionally sized screens.    If there is a weakness to \\"Hubble 3D,\\" it's that it doesn't spend enough time on its subject. It clocks in at a measly forty-five minutes - on television, that would amount to an hour-long special. I would have greatly appreciated an expansion of telescope's history, including who designed it, how it was funded, when it was built, how it affected popular culture, and so on. The images it has captured, after all, are the reason we can create such accurate computer generated maps of nebulas and galaxies. I don't believe we can truly appreciate the contributions the Hubble has made without first knowing what went into making them possible. Sure, any book or internet site can fill you in on the details, but if you're already at the theater, you might as well learn everything you need to know there.

B002VECM6S|5.0|Well acted, well scripted, well directed--this movie pretty much has it all.  It's also a great reminder of the kind of differences in the lives of others that we can make as human beings.  Overall, one of the better films I've seen in a while.
B001KVZ6G6|5.0|I'm not sure if this is the best movie I've ever seen, but for the life of me I can't think of one better.  I'm not usually a watcher of Pixar stuff for some reason, indeed the last one I'd seen was the first Toy Story.  No good reason why that's so, I just never got around to them.  But something about the premise of Up grabbed me, so when I saw it in a used DVD bin, I snagged it.  Two watchings in two days later, and I ordered this particular Blu-Ray copy of it, after bragging about Up to anyone and everyone I came across.    What's great about it?  Where do I start?  First, there's the house made of balloons.  It makes for amazing cover art, and arouses curiousity.  Petty you think?  Not really, the eye likes what the eye likes, and that's not to be discounted.  The characters for another.  Carl Frederickson isn't some to good to be true hero or precocious kid, he's a crotchety old man who actually behaves like an old man.  Go figure eh?  He doesn't look much like voice talent Ed Asner, but Asner's voice is letter perfect for the performance.  His sidekick, Russell, voiced by Jordan Nagai, acts just like a little kid would act.  He's very observant at times, but naive and obtuse a lot of the time as well, just like a real life version of Russell would be.  The two of them make for a great team, even if Carl is a little slow to grasp that.  And that's what's terrific about the roles, neither of them know everything, or instantly figure out what to do.  They have to think, and the movie shows them thinking. Not a lot of movies have the patience, or the sense, to allow its characters to think.  But Up does.  The supporting characters, like Christopher Plummer's Charles Muntz, the dog Dug, and all the rest are excellently handled as well.      The highlight of the supporting characters, for me, was the young/old versions of Ellie Frederickson.  The young version is voiced by the director's daughter, and she has the right bit of spunk and adventure for the shy and callow Carl (they look to be about 8-10 years old in those scenes).  The adult version, who marries Carl, is done without a voice, and is part of the most touching montage I've ever seen on screen.  We watch 50 years of their lives in a few minutes, with no dialogue, yet it spoke volumes.  This is why the cliche \\"A picture is worth a thousand words\\" is so relevant even today.  I think I've watched it five or six times and I still tear up during it.    The computer artistry is what one expects from Pixar, even someone like me who isn't a habitual watcher of their films.  The balloon house, the airship, the dogs (don't laugh, they're a riot), all of it was done with amazing technical proficiency, and always adds to the story.    But it really comes back to Carl and Russell in the end.  I cared about them, what happened to them, and more importantly what they took out of those adventures.  I've not heard anything about an Up sequel, and there's nothing on its Wikipedia page, but I would love to see another adventure with the two of them in it.  Either way, Pixar has made a fan out of me for a long time, I hope they can keep it up.    Five stars
